Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: CDRIVE: Cognitive Radio Enabled Spectrum Aware Intelligent Vehicular Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Transferring high bandwidth content is a challenge in vehicular and mobile networks that are limited by spectrum scarcity in the unlicensed bands, short connection times, and the cost of cellular data plans. These observations motivate the use of frequency agile cognitive radios as part of the project called CDRIVE (for Cognitive raDio enabled spectRum-aware Intelligent Vehicular nEtworks). CDRIVE involves the use of theoretical analysis tools and exploration of correlation functions. A major contribution lies in creating a new ns-2 based simulation tool that combines spectrum-related functions in a cognitive radio within a vehicular environment. CDRIVE makes advances towards developing a holistic framework for vehicular cognitive radios networks for allocating roadside base station locations that have spectrum database access capability, enhancing the science of collecting spectrum measurements under different topographical conditions, surrounding urban structures and speeds, and devising a new rate control mechanism that anticipates network and correlated road congestions, and intermittent disruptions due to spectrum outages. CDRIVE will yield insights on integrating cognitive radios with spectrum databases, especially for mobile networks, which are now mandated by the FCC. It will provide the theory and practical validation of the best mobility-aware spectrum-sensing strategies, and tightly couple the external environment with the sensing method. It will also shape future safety-related messaging in vehicles, support real-time telemetry analysis, and allow high-bandwidth communication for emergency response personnel.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent strides made in vehicular technology have resulted in a vast array of networked sensors assisting in vehicle operation, as well as raised consumer expectations of safety and comfort. In modern cars, thousands of sensor signals are continuously exchanged, and there is an emerging trend to retrieve this data in real time safety analysis. The short connection times associated with exchanging this information necessitate identifying efficient ways of using the available wireless spectrum and identifying new communication opportunities using dynamic spectrum access and cognitive radio technology that allows opportunistic use of licensed frequency bands. Project CDRIVE (for Cognitive raDio enabled spectRum-aware Intelligent Vehicular nEtworks) has resulted in the design of a robust connectivity paradigm composed of vehicles equipped with frequency agile distributed and mobile cognitive radios. In summary, this project has created- (i) an analytical framework for determining the topology of a cognitive radio vehicular network for allocating roadside BS locations for data offloading depending upon various application-specific quality of service metrics, traffic conditions, access policies, and GPS capability that may be present within the vehicles, (ii) a cooperative spectrum sensing-decision framework that allows each cognitive radio enabled vehicle to merge spectrum information from other neighboring vehicles, as well as leveraging locally gathered measurements, (iii) reliable end to end upper layer TCP protocols for spectrum changing environments that enhance classical and well established flavors likes TCP NewReno, as well as approach the problem through TCP-friendly techniques, (iv) joint sensing and spectrum database access techniques to ensure the most accurate spectrum usage data is available prior to transmissions.

This project has led to an effective demonstration of establishing a collaboration towards solving a common problem using teams that span across different countries (in this case between the US and Finland), sharing know-hows, tackling implementation road blocks and co-authoring joint publications despite the challenges introduced through the large distances between research groups, cultural differences, and limited in-person contact between the PIs.

The project has involved developing alternate forms of emergency communication, which will also be useful for planning the actions of emergency responders in events like earthquakes, tsunamis, and large-scale man-made disasters that pose unforeseen challenges resulting in serious spectrum and traffic jamming. Finally, the project has resulted in creating innovative activity-based learning experiences for high school students. This activity involves demonstrations with wireless sensors and networks, as well as showing what a wireless signal looks like using equipment in the laboratory.
